ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Maria Pozimski
Instructor: Hui Li  Li, Hui
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie Schultz
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie Schultz

Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  This review is actually for my TF, Maria Pozimski, who for some raeson was not an option in the above menu. Maria was an excellent, super-knowledgeable, always accessible TF. All below answers pertain to Maria, rather than NAtalie.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kelly did a great job and was always very helpful answering questions!
Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  Kellie was fantastic. Was able to push me to think about my project in a different way that made the entire semester come together. I really appreciated her.
Instructor: Eleanor Catherine Stokes  X. Lee and L. Bonneau led discussions Maria P. was excellent, excellent, excellent in all respects as a TF; Kellie (Eleanor) also excellent
Instructor: Hui Li  For all of the TA's, It would have been nice to get feedback on the labs. For some I have no idea what I did wrong.

Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie was an excellent teaching assistant. She made herself available during lab section for us to ask questions. Her presentations during lecture were also straightforward and helpful.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie is easily approachable and very knowledgable. She is helpful during lab sections.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Extremely responsive, very willing to chat, good ideas

Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Natalie is very helpful in the lab (and with homework assignments). She is very knowledgeable about remote sensing techniques. She was very responsive to my questions and made herself very accessible for feedback and troubleshooting in the lab.
Instructor: Natalie Marie Schultz  Super helpful trouble-shooter during lab times, clear passion for RS which was contagious, mellow attitude that helped diffuse stress that often comes with labs.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Overall I thought the course was very useful and I learned a lot. I felt that there was maybe too much emphasis on the physics behind remote sensing at the front end of the course - some of this could be replaced with more applied learning.

I personally did not find the field trip to be particularly helpful. It took a considerable amount of time to make a point that I think is mostly self-explanatory. Perhaps, make this field trip optional?

Xuhui was a fantastic instructor. He explains concepts clearly and at just the right pace. He has a genuine character, which makes the course even more enjoyable. He was very approachable and open to addressing students questions.

Remote sensing technology is fantastic, and I'm glad to have learned a bit of it. The class itself left a lot to be desired. The instruction was difficult to follow, and the connection between lecture and lab was often unclear.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Being able to complete a final project

I think the project was great because it allowed each student to dive into their particular area of interest, and use the tools that we had been taught all semester. I also think the field trip was fun and informative! Some of the guest lecturers at the end of the semester were also interesting (the guy on the last day who worked with NASA...not so much)

The final project was the best aspect of the course. While lectures were informative and helpful to understand the concepts used in Remote Sensing, the practice of using remote sensing to answer a given question was the best experience.
I really enjoyed learning the concepts at the beginning of the course. I also learned a tremendous amount from working on my final project.
Working on the course project was very helpful to individual learning. Larry was very helpful with guiding the final projects and is very knowledgeable.

I really loved learning the different techniques, technology, sensors, and the scientific background in this course. Professor Lee provides very clear instruction. Application of remote sensing techniques seem almost boundless and this class left me with a sense of excited anticipation not only for the future of remote sensing but also for the ways that these techniques can be applied to my work today and into the future! An awesome introduction with very useful hands-on experience in the lab portion.
Great teaching, lab and project were useful for learning.
Lab excercises

Good content, relevant to learning satellite image analysis Well-prepared lectures Very good lab exercises, which really major weekly projects Good order of presentation of content Good guest lecturers
Larry is an absolute gem. He is so kind and helpful. The groundtruthing field trip was also great.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I wish that my own project work could have been integrated into the labs, for example, applying new techniques but to our own data. I think this would have incentivized me to to the labs better and probably would have helped improve my final project. As mentioned above, I think that some of the early teaching on physics was less useful, and could be traded out with more applied teaching (I've already forgotten all of the equations we had to learn, for example). I think it could be really interesting to instead assign scientific papers that use remote sensing in different areas, and then discuss in detail how these projects were done (Dr. Seto's presentation was the most similar to this approach).

I really didn't like the way that this class was structured; I wish there had been less theoretical material and more time working with, and getting comfortable with ENVI. The labs were okay, but they didn't really require much thought and could be really boring because of the repetitive nature of some of the lab report questions. It might have been more interesting to start the project earlier so people can pick an area of study, and then do the lab exercises based on their regions of study. The results from some of the labs could then be incorporated into the project. I also think the problem sets were a total waste of time and felt like undergraduate busy work. For example, problem set one had about 10 questions where all we were doing was converting units. Either you know how to do a conversion or you don't; we don't need to be repeating that process over and over as some form of a rote exercise.
The field trip was not very useful and involved hopping on and off the bus a lot. It would have been more fun to do a walking field trip instead.

I really enjoyed the course, but I think that the assignments could be adjusted to improve the course overall. After spring break I would have preferred to focus entirely on my final project. Instead, I spent almost all of my available time in the lab trying to complete the lab assignments. The labs were helpful at the beginning of the course, but I think it would be more useful to stop having lab assignments, and give students that time to work on their projects. Maybe, make the labs available for review in case a student wants to use that particular tool in their project. The class already takes up a considerable amount of time, and I could only allocate so much to both the labs and the final project.

The lab exercises could be improved. I appreciate that there is a lab section for this course but the labs feel like pushing buttons and I didn't fully learn or understand how to use ENVI until it came time to do the course project. The labs are great resources for the course projects because the instructions are so detailed.
I think the course is very well put-together and would recommend it to anyone as-is.

I did not learn much about troubleshooting within ENVI because all the labs were so prescribed. Is there a way to make the labs just as informative and low-stress, without having them be so prescribed and giving students a chance to troubleshoot on their own? Also, lectures in the second half of the semester were not as relevant. There were some that seemed like they were just trying to fill time, especially guest speaker Dr. Ashton.

Lectures, although among the best-prepared on campus, lose a lot of worth by only being available late the night before they are presented, so it is impossible to prepare them unless one wants to get little sleep the night before this morning class Exam is too long Ungraded course requirements Inaccurate information on course-integral CEO website, long into the semester Posting student names and materials publicly without student consent Using grading criteria that are not for components taught in the course Unbelievably little feedback on the written and compiled major course project, while feedback that was given was mostly for the brief presentation, which is listed as ungraded Grade for final project based almost completely on the supposedly ungraded presentation and very little on all of the work that went into the paper Three weeks is not enough time for preparation of a project that is expected to be completed to the caliber of a major presentation and thesis; grading favor is heavily slanted toward students who have a major project on which to draw from outside this class Project is presented as exploratory yet graded as if it was to have reached a certain completion point, again favoring students with a major project from outside the course Other components interfere with what is laughably presented as three weeks to work on course project Field trip held during the three-week project period, also during major holy days for several faiths First of the three in-class project-prep lab days is spent mostly discussing and preparing the field trip, second project prep day spent writing up the ungraded field trip, third day lab is too crowded with people from the other lab sections Course project is so extensive that it interferes with other courses at a very busy time of the semester; extent of project is fine, and projects are the most important part of course, but more time is needed for them, and student time needs to be respected, unfettered by discussion, previous-lab completion and field trip components Lab staff seemed to pick and choose whom to help for projects, how much and when, at a time when a let-them-figure-it-out approach is not useful; lab staff sometimes spent extensive time chatting with some people even though having told others no time to even answer a question Lab staff discussed student work habits and work styles and preferences behind their backs, not good practice even though names were not named During presentations, some students were supported and others were treated rudely by course leaders, inappropriate even if presentation is seen as poor That this puzzling end of semester time can be experienced as not supportive of learning and overly stressful, and the course can still be held as very good means, both that a lot of work has gone into preparing the course and that more attention needs to be given to the student experience of the course as a fair, supportive, respectful of students, if appropriately challenging, learning experience.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes - I think linking final project more directly with the labs could be useful, especially the last few labs that were completed while working on the final project. At that time I was excited about the project and the labs felt more like busy work.

Again, I think that the lecture material needs to be better tied into the labs. The lectures seemed very theoretical, whereas the labs were very applied. It would have been nice to have more of a bridge between the two (maybe talk about different applications during the lectures, rather than just the theory or physics or statistics behind a new tool).

The lab assignments often took a very long time to complete. Towards the end of the course, I found that completing the lab assignments took away from the time I needed to work on my project. Maybe ending the labs a week or 2 sooner would be helpful to make sure the project gets the time it needs.
Labs related to lecture material very well.

I really liked learning the scientific background in class and hands-on remote sensing techniques in the lab. It was so fun to learn about clouds and light more in depth than I had previously. Very engaging and the material really sparked my imagination and curiosity for climate, weather, and Earth!
I think they are great
Good

This relationship was often unclear, as I believe the lectures and labs were developed separate from one another. Perhaps having the TA's briefly go over what concepts we should be honing in on in the lab would be useful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was an exciting area to study in and I wish we had more remote sensing classes!
This course is essential to my research. It will also be an excellent skill to have as I move forward with a possible career in conservation and natural resource management.
Learning remote sensing tools is a great addition to the other geospatial courses offered at FES.

Remote sensing, as an ever-growing science, is on the cutting edge of a lot of ecological research these days. I am pleased that Yale offers this course as an excellent introduction to the concepts and techniques behind this field. This course has added a valuable knowledge-base and skill-set to my toolkit.
Geo-spatial focus

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To see if remote sensing could be used in my own work (which is more in the social and policy sciences), and to build on spatial analytical skills more broadly.
It sounded really interesting and had good reviews. I also think that being able to use new technologies, like remote sensing, can improve my research.
I wanted to gain a new skill, and better understand how this technology works.
To learn a new program and to learn a new way of analyzing environmental change.
I wanted to learn more about the capabilities and techniques of remote sensing, for application in my current and future work.
I am interested in GIS and remote sensing is a major part of it. This class would give me insightful details of remote sensing application and would inspire me in my own field.
Geo-spatial focus

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes, I think I got what I wanted out of the course, but think I could have gotten much more if the course were structured differently
yes
Yes, I learned an incredible amount in just one semester, and I hope to continue using and building on the skills that I learned.
Exceeded expectations. Glad I took this course.
Yes, above and beyond.
Yes. Remote sensing is not relevant to my own research but I gain skills of how to use this tool.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: No work group defined as such, but fellow students were very supportive to learning, and I hope I was the same

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's definitely a heavy time commitment, but you will get a strong introduction to remote sensing.
Start the project early!

Allow yourself plenty of time to complete the lab exercises (even more than the 3 hours of your lab period.) Start on your project early. Take extensive notes in lecture because the book and the lecture slides do not have all the information that you'll need. If your physics is rusty, seek outside help in preparation for the midterm.
Have a few potential projects in mind. Make sure that you have the time available to dedicate to this course because it is demanding.

The material at the beginning of the course might seem difficult but don't let that discourage you from taking the course. After the midterm the course load is very doable. You'll learn a lot from the course project.

Observing the Earth From Space, aside from having the best course title at the school, is an engaging introduction to remote sensing techniques and concepts. I highly recommend this course and the resources at the Yale Center for Earth Observation! You will leave this course with a treasure box of ideas and skills for answering questions about more topics than you can imagine! Enjoy!
Try to think of final project topic early and do some feasibility researches.

If you have a geo-spatial focus, or need and want to learn how to analyze satellite images, take the course Stay ahead on everything from homework to extensive weekly lab projects to presentation prep to paper prep Don't spend time on the field report if it is still ungraded; you won't even get feedback on it, and it takes precious time away from project work If possible, start project before the three-week project period Practice your presentation ahead of time, and prepare it well, because it counts toward your project grade even though Canvas may say it does not count Work quickly on the exam, keeping answers short Read the textbook You will learn the most through the lab exercises, so make time to complete them each week; take them seriously
It's best if you have a project in mind when you enter the class. It is great for MESc and PhD students.
